00012 template<class T>
00013 class Singleton
00014 {
00015 public:
00017    static T& Instance()
00018    {
00019       if( !mp_instance )
00020       {
00021          try
00022          {
00023             mp_instance = new T;
00024          }
00025          catch(Exception& e)
00026          {
00027             throw;
00028          }
00029 
00030          m_destroyer.SetSingleton(mp_instance);
00031       }
00032 
00033       return *mp_instance;
00034    }
00035 
00036 protected:
00037    /* No constructor is available. The singleton design pattern
00038       doesn't allow the creation of multiple instances of an object. */
00039    Singleton() {}
00040    Singleton(const Singleton&) {}
00041    ~Singleton() {}
00042    const Singleton& operator=(const Singleton&) { return *this; }
00043 
00044    friend class SingletonDestroyer<T>;
00045 
00046 private:
00048    static T* mp_instance;
00049    static SingletonDestroyer<T> m_destroyer;
00050 
00051 };
00052 
00053 template<class T> T* Singleton<T>::mp_instance = 0;
00054 template<class T> SingletonDestroyer<T> Singleton<T>::m_destroyer;
00055 
00056 template<class T>
00057 class SingletonDestroyer
00058 {
00059    public:
00060       SingletonDestroyer(T* s = 0)
00061       {
00062          _singleton = s;
00063       }
00064 
00065       ~SingletonDestroyer()
00066       {
00067          delete _singleton;
00068       }
00069 
00070       void SetSingleton(T* s)
00071       {
00072          _singleton = s;
00073       }
00074 
00075 private:
00076       T* _singleton;
00077 };
